author: By Matthew Futterman
title: ATP Will Investigate Domestic Abuse Allegations Against Alexander Zverev
description: The German tennis star has denied he abused Olya Sharypova during a series of physical altercations she says took place in 2019.
content: After months of delay and complaints from players and tennis officials, the men’s professional tennis tour announced Monday that it would investigate Alexander Zverev after accusations of domestic abuse made by a former girlfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Smith
title: ‘Zombie’ Urchins Are Destroying Kelp Forests. Can’t We Just Eat Them?
description: The spiny creatures have destroyed nearly all of California’s kelp forests, what marine biologists call “the lungs of the ocean.”
content: ALBION, Calif. — A decade ago, when Gary Trumper used to dive for sea urchins, the docks here were packed with commercial fishing vessels. Mr. Trumper and his diving partner, Byron Koehler, would steer through masses of tangled kelp and return after a few hours of work with what Mr. Koehler described as enough red urchin to sink their 26-foot boat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day:
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 4, 2021.
content: “I am 21st in the tradition. By the time I live my life and I pass my legacy to my son, I doubt that the last of the houses will also be open.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Pfizer vaccine provides 90 percent protection against hospitalization for six months, study finds.
description: The findings, which also document a waning of protection against infection, come as officials debate the necessity and timing of booster shots.
content: The Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine is 90 percent effective at preventing hospitalization for up to six months, with no signs of waning during that time period, according to a large new U.S. study conducted by researchers at Pfizer and Kaiser Permanente.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A New ‘Pal Joey’ Is Broadway Bound
description: The show will be rewritten for a production set on the South Side of Chicago in the 1940s, directed by Tony Goldwyn and Savion Glover.
content: “Pal Joey” is coming back to Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Facebook Is Weaker Than We Knew
description: A trove of leaked documents, published by The Wall Street Journal, hints at a company whose best days are behind it.
content: One possible way to read “The Facebook Files,” The Wall Street Journal’s excellent series of reports based on leaked internal Facebook research, is as a story about an unstoppable juggernaut bulldozing society on its way to the bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Johnson & Johnson to Seek F.D.A. Authorization for Booster Shot
description: The request, expected this week, comes after a study found the company’s vaccine was only 71 percent effective against hospitalization from Covid-19.
content: WASHINGTON — Johnson & Johnson is planning to ask federal regulators early this week to authorize a booster shot of its coronavirus vaccine, according to officials familiar with the company’s plans. The firm is the last of the three federally authorized vaccine providers to call for extra injections, amid mounting evidence that at least the elderly and other high-risk groups need more protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: Should There Be Limits on How Much Time Young People Spend Playing Video Games?
description: Should governments set those limits? Should parents and families? Or should young people be able to make their own decisions?
content: China announced this summer that children and teenagers can now play just three hours of video games a week. Young people under 18 are barred from online gaming on school days, and limited to one hour a day on weekend and holiday evenings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Dana Rubinstein
title: Eric Adams Rakes in $7.7 Million, With Help From Wealthy Donors
description: With victory nearly assured, Mr. Adams has amassed a substantial war chest ahead of the general election for New York City mayor. His opponent lags far behind.
content: Eric Adams is heavily favored to become the next mayor of New York City, but that hasn’t stopped him from amassing an intimidatingly large war chest ahead of November’s general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Devastating Ways Depression and Anxiety Impact the Body
description: Mind and body form a two-way street.
content: It’s no surprise that when a person gets a diagnosis of heart disease, cancer or some other life-limiting or life-threatening physical ailment, they become anxious or depressed. But the reverse can also be true: Undue anxiety or depression can foster the development of a serious physical disease, and even impede the ability to withstand or recover from one. The potential consequences are particularly timely, as the ongoing stress and disruptions of the pandemic continue to take a toll on mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: After Ozy’s Carlos Watson Talks of a Comeback, a Key Investor Objects
description: Mr. Watson, the head of Ozy Media, said in an interview on NBC’s “Today” show that Ozy “is going to open for business.” Ron Conway, an early investor, was critical of his remarks.
content: Hours after Carlos Watson, the chief executive of Ozy Media, appeared on morning news programs to say he would revive his company, which announced on Friday that it had shut down, a prominent early investor in Ozy demanded that he spend its remaining cash to pay its employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: A Textile Designer Who Draws on Art History and Neuroscience
description: An antidote to earth-toned minimalism, Ellen Van Dusen’s designs suggest that children aren’t the only ones drawn to bold colors and shapes.
content: As a child, Ellen Van Dusen became fixated on the kinetic colors in the artist Ellsworth Kelly’s paintings, which she’d come upon during her frequent museum visits in Washington, D.C., where she grew up. She was puzzled by Kelly’s abstract minimalist works, several of which comprise flat, solid stretches of a single shade; “I was like, ‘It’s just a green canvas; what’s wrong with my brain?’” says the 35-year-old owner of the textiles and home-accessories brand Dusen Dusen. Such questions stuck with her when she was an undergraduate at Tufts, where she majored in a multidisciplinary mix of art history, neuroscience and visual anthropology. “I studied the visual process from different angles,” she says. “Neuroscience is where I focused on vision: how things come through the eye, how they’re processed through the brain and what evolutionarily draws the eye.” But she kept coming back to color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Hilliards Chocolates Enters the Pumpkin Spice Chat
description: The nearly century old Massachusetts chocolatier has released a line of limited-edition caramels that taste like autumn.
content: With fall comes pumpkin spice. But before you say “Oh no!” consider the ever so subtle caramels from Hilliards Chocolates, a company that is almost 100 years old and has stores in Norwell, North Easton and Mansfield, Mass. Each chewy bite coated in dark chocolate with seasonal orange tracing delivers a whiff of warming pumpkin spice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Party Shirt Is Here to Bust That Viral Life Hack
description: The duo has found fame on TikTok with a mix of music, food reviews and debunks.
content: Names: Xavier Di Petta and Nick Iavarone
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Klein
title: Joe Klein Explains How the History of Four Centuries Ago Still Shapes American Culture and Politics
description: David Hackett Fischer’s “Albion’s Seed,” published in 1989, describes today’s United States with stunning prescience.
content: Through the spring and summer, I’ve been watching the daily maps of Covid-19 cases and vaccinations — the diagonal slash through Appalachia and the South to the Ozarks and Texas, where cases soared; the high vaccination rates in New England — and I’ve thought back to “Albion’s Seed: Four British Folkways in America,” David Hackett Fischer’s classic history of British migration to colonial America, which was published in 1989 and explained these phenomena with a clarity that seems even more stunning today. The divide between maskers and anti-maskers, vaxxers and anti-vaxxers is as old as Plymouth Rock. It is deeper than politics; it is cultural.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Did Death Cheat Stephen Hawking of a Nobel Prize?
description: A recent study of black holes confirmed a fundamental prediction that the theoretical physicist made nearly five decades ago. But the ultimate award is beyond his reach.
content: Did death cheat Stephen Hawking of a Nobel Prize?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bridgett M. Davis
title: Jocelyn Nicole Johnson Makes Virginia’s Past Present in ‘My Monticello.’
description: A debut fiction collection imagines Black characters reckoning with this country’s legacy — and present reality — of white violence.
content: MY MONTICELLO FictionBy Jocelyn Nicole Johnson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Prasenjeet Yadav
title: A Dispatch From an Endangered Bird’s ‘Garden of Eden’
description: Immerse yourself in the visual splendor of a tiny volcanic island in the northern Andaman Sea, the only home of the little-known Narcondam hornbill.
content: By the end of 2019, I was ready for a change of scenery. Working as a natural history photographer, I’d spent the previous two years tracking snow leopards in the Himalayas. Then, one snowy afternoon, I received a brief call from Dr. Rohit Naniwadekar, a bird biologist with the Nature Conservation Foundation. He asked me to get to a small volcanic island in the northern Andaman Sea as quickly as I possibly could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Supply-chain snarls reach the book publishing industry.
description: The churning disruption in the global supply chain has now reached the world of books, just as the holiday season — a crucial time for publishers and bookstores — approaches.
content: The churning disruption in the global supply chain has now reached the world of books, just as the holiday season — a crucial time for publishers and bookstores — approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christina Anderson
title: Swedish Artist Known for Muhammad Caricature Dies in Car Crash
description: The artist, Lars Vilks, had been under police protection since 2010, after his sketch prompted widespread condemnation from Muslims. He was killed along with two bodyguards in a crash that the police said was an accident.
content: Lars Vilks, an artist and free speech activist whose cartoon depiction of the Prophet Muhammad on the body of a dog in 2007 made him the target of numerous assassination attempts, was killed in a car crash in Sweden on Sunday, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: New Condiments to Add Kick to Dinner
description: Maya Kaimal’s new green and red chili sauces deliver heat and flavor.
content: Maya Kaimal, whose company produces myriad sauces, condiments and other ingredients for Indian cooking, has just introduced hot sauces. Not that her marinades, simmer sauces and ketchup lacked that kick, but these newcomers, inspired by her family’s recipes from Kerala, are designed to deliver compelling heat when drizzled on vegetables, eggs, cheese and seafood. The green combines forceful serrano chiles and ginger with a sweet note from coconut cream; the red’s Kashmiri chiles and red jalapeños are tempered by tamarind’s citric tartness. They come in convenient squeeze bottles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: Kamla Bhasin, a First-Wave South Asian Feminist, Dies at 75
description: An activist, poet and author, she spent most of her adult life fighting injustice and patriarchy and building bonds of solidarity with women across borders.
content: NEW DELHI — Kamla Bhasin, an activist, poet and writer who was an early leader of the women’s movement in India, died here on Sept. 25. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Peter Eavis
title: Energy Prices Spike as Producers Worry Over Pandemic and Climate
description: Even as more costly fuel poses political risks for President Biden, oil companies and OPEC are not eager to produce more because they worry prices will drop.
content: HOUSTON — Americans are spending a dollar more for a gallon of gasoline than they were a year ago. Natural gas prices have shot up more than 150 percent over the same time, threatening to raise prices of food, chemicals, plastic goods and heat this winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: José Andrés Expands His Mail Order Offerings
description: The Spanish chef now sells paella, steaks and tapas through Goldbelly.
content: José Andrés, the Spanish chef and restaurateur known for feeding those in need through his organization, World Central Kitchen, is ready to ship some of his specialties to food-lovers able to pay a substantial price. While his paella kits were available in the New York area through his Mercado Little Spain in Hudson Yards, Goldbelly has given him the ability to go wider with a collection of dinners, along with the makings of a tapas party. Some cooking and other prep work is required; the ingredients are shipped frozen or chilled. There’s paella with red shrimp ($179, serving three), Ibérico pork steak with aioli and pan con tomate ($199, serving four), Wagyu rib-eye steak with a salad ($329, serving six) and tapas of charcuterie, cheese, croquettes and pan con tomate ($179, serving four to six). Cheesecake meets crème brûlée in the burnt Basque cheesecake for $109 to serve 12. The prices include shipping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: ‘It’s Like Kismet’: How a Long-Empty Building Found the Perfect Tenant
description: This old, triangular clinic was created to serve the poor and infirm. God’s Love We Deliver was up to the task.
content: When New York City locked down in March 2020, the meal delivery organization God’s Love We Deliver received 3,500 calls from people seeking help in a single weekend. By the end of June that year, the number of daily meals it was producing had increased by 2,500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rose Courteau
title: A Floral Designer Who Heightens the Drama of Nature
description: Drawing on a fantastical aesthetic sense partly formed in childhood, Doan Ly makes arrangements — and equally alluring photos of them — that are rich in color and narrative.
content: I met the floral designer Doan Ly at her studio, an industrial loft near the Brooklyn Navy Yard that she shares with the interior plant designer Lisa Muñoz. Stems littered the cement floor, and one of Ly’s assistants, Myke Marinkovich, was tidying up the work space with cheery efficiency. Ly showed me some garden roses, plucking them out of a water bucket and pinching their petals delicately between her fingers as she pointed out the complex, open structure that differentiates them from more tightly petaled varieties. “I love romantic flowers,” she said. “I love having the chance to be around a lush, really overgrown, gushy world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eviana Hartman
title: An Artist Couple Who Live Among the Furniture They Create Together
description: Though they maintain separate practices, Chris Johanson and Johanna Jackson regularly collaborate on hand-hewn pieces that are subtly autobiographical.
content: For the artists Chris Johanson and Johanna Jackson, the border between art and design is as blurred as that between work and life. The couple, based in Portland, Ore., and Los Angeles, have been married for 18 years and have worked under the same roof, more or less, since first striking up a friendship in a San Francisco bookstore in the ’90s. And though the bulk of their oeuvres are distinct — Johanson is considered a linchpin of the Mission School, the post-punk movement that borrowed from both graffiti and folk art, for his colorful semi-figurative paintings, while Jackson is known for exploring the poetic and surrealist potential of handmade household objects, as with a U-shaped porcelain candelabra or a sculpture that incorporates sweaters she hand-knit — the couple have also been quietly collaborating for a decade on collage-like salvaged-wood furniture and functional structures, which populate their own home and studios. This fall, some of these pieces will make their way into his-and-hers solo shows in New York (Johanson’s opens in October at Mitchell-Innes & Nash, Jackson’s in November at Tennis Elbow at The Journal Gallery), each offering an immersive view of the artists’ range and overlap during this recent housebound era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Britain’s Christmas Lament: Meat Shortages and Delivery Delays
description: Military personnel are driving transport trucks. Pig farmers may start culling their stock. Even the government says shortages will affect Christmas, as Britons brace for a challenging winter.
content: BUNGAY, England — To understand the deep sense of anxiety Britons feel about the supply shortages currently afflicting the nation — and threatening disruptions to the Christmas dinner table — one need only travel to Simon Watchorn’s pig farm, about two hours northeast of London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Andrew Yang Says He Left Democratic Party to Become Independent
description: Mr. Yang, who ran unsuccessfully for president in 2020 and for mayor of New York this year, said he could be more “honest” about politics if he were not a Democrat.
content: Andrew Yang, the former long-shot presidential candidate and onetime technology entrepreneur, announced on Monday that he had left the Democratic Party and become an independent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Facebook, Nobel Prizes, Captain Kirk: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: ‘Profit Over Safety’
description: A Facebook whistle-blower explains her motivations.
content: The hits keep coming for Facebook. Last night, in an interview on “60 Minutes,” a former Facebook product manager described how she had leaked internal documents to The Wall Street Journal. The newspaper had published a series of eye-opening articles dubbed “The Facebook Files,” detailing what the social media giant knew about the harms its platform was causing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: A Rita Moreno Documentary and ‘Ghosts’
description: “Rita Moreno: Just a Girl Who Decided to Go for It” airs on PBS. And a new sitcom debuts on CBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Banana as Muse
description: A new group show at Fort Makers in the Lower East Side honors one of the world’s most popular fruits.
content: Homage to the banana plays out at a display at Fort Makers, a design studio and gallery run by artists in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. It was inspired by news of a deadly pathogen infecting banana farms. The show is meant to celebrate the threatened fruit. Historical pieces and newly commissioned works share the gallery. There’s a machine-tufted rug called “War Rug,” with references to banana republics, by Johannah Herr; Rebecca Morgan’s ironic “Banana Smile”; and a banana scarf by Lilian Martinez. The works are for sale, $250 to $80,000. The exhibition will be up through Nov. 28 from noon to 6 p.m. on Wednesdays and Sundays, and from noon to 7 p.m. Thursdays through Saturdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: With Biden’s Agenda in the Balance, Lobbying Kicks Into High Gear
description: Business interests are using ads and other efforts to cajole Democrats to change or kill a $3.5 trillion social policy bill.
content: WASHINGTON — As centrist Democrats in Congress have worked to block or strip out major provisions of President Biden’s $3.5 trillion social safety net and climate plan, a string of online ads has popped up in their states and districts, lavishing praise on them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: England’s international Covid travel rules have been simplified.
description: The change, which came into force on Monday, replaced a traffic light-inspired system with a single “red” list of places that present the highest virus risk.
content: LONDON — Streamlined coronavirus restrictions on international travel in and out of England came into effect on Monday, including an easing of testing and quarantine requirements for fully vaccinated arrivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meara Sharma
title: The Artist Who Dreamed Up a Kaleidoscopic Basketball Court for London’s Canary Wharf
description: Yinka Ilori brings color and joy to an eclectic array of projects, whether he’s reimagining public spaces or designing furniture and housewares.
content: Having grown up in a vibrant multicultural community of immigrants in London, Yinka Ilori was acutely aware of color from a young age. “I would go to these parties and see a cluster of my mom’s friends wearing pink, and another cluster of women wearing purple, and the men wearing green,” recalls the 34-year-old Nigerian-British artist and designer, describing how groups of friends would purchase the same fabric and orchestrate matching outfits for celebrations. Those early memories of “color blocking,” as he calls it, eventually found vivid expression in Ilori’s work: The artist uses kaleidoscopic hues and energetic shapes in an eclectic range of projects, from architecture and furniture to public sculpture and urban interventions. Whether he’s creating carnivalesque cultural and social spaces (like his summer installation in the courtyard of London’s historic Somerset House) or reimagining forgotten elements of the cityscape (swathing a dreary underpass in rainbow tones), he seeks to spark euphoria and foster connection via an aesthetic that marries the sensory richness of his Nigerian heritage with pristine yet provocative designs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Major Labels’ Wraps Popular Music — All of It — in a Warm Embrace
description: In his first book, Kelefa Sanneh considers the past 50 years of music, writing appreciatively about everything from R&B to “bro country.”
content: It’s rare for a book of poetry in America to get a negative review. It’s always been so. The field is so small, the stakes so apparently low, that pricking any but the most inflated reputation can seem, as the phrase goes, like breaking a butterfly on a wheel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Californians View Abortion
description: About one in five support Roe v. Wade being overturned, a number that has remained largely unchanged for more than a decade.
content: The hundreds of women’s marches staged across the country over the weekend had a clear rallying cry: Don’t let America go the way of Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Pro Tennis Finds New Cities to Play In, but Will It Return?
description: The pandemic caused many tennis events to be canceled or rescheduled. It also created opportunities for U.S. cities to throw one together.
content: SAN DIEGO — The small tennis stadium was packed and in full roar as Daniel Vallverdú watched Casper Ruud and Grigor Dimitrov trade blows and breaks of serve on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Book for Your Johnny Appleseed
description: “Odd Apples” contains colorful portraits of some lesser-known apples like the knobbed russet from England.
content: How apples grow and reproduce, and the history, evolution and symbolism of the fruit are discussed in a compelling introduction in “Odd Apples,” a new book of apple photographs. The sometimes surprising photos display the colorful varieties, many with red or pink flesh. You’ll discover the fancifully striped Red St. Lawrence from Maine, the sleek Arkansas Black, the ruby Hidden Rose from Oregon, the pearly Yellow Transparent from Russia and several tortured knobbed russets from Sussex, England. At the end there’s a paragraph devoted to each one. The book, representing three years work, comes in a large format that includes a print of the Hidden Rose apple; a smaller, less expensive version of the book does not.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Shopping for Decorative Boxes
description: The best ones hold ‘any sort of unsightly things’ — but they’re also interesting pieces of functional art. (And no, they don’t have to be square.)
content: The best decorative boxes are both storage containers and functional art: They corral little things like jewelry and office supplies, but they’re also interesting on their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Monica Lewinsky Has Some Things to Say About Cancel Culture
description: The activist and producer reflects on how the internet and social media have changed public discourse since her 1998 saga.
content: Truth and context may seem elusive today, but for Monica Lewinsky they both “went out the door in 1998.” As the investigation into Bill Clinton unfolded, Lewinsky came under scrutiny as the most infamous intern in Washington, but kept largely silent due to an immunity deal with investigators. In this conversation with Kara Swisher, Lewinsky says she and the other women entangled in the president’s impeachment “were all reduced in different ways to serve purposes for other people: for either political points or to make money.” She considers the toll of that experience on her own life, and contemplates how it might all have played out differently in the age of online accountability and the #MeToo Twittersphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Ruhl
title: An Acclaimed Playwright on Masks and the Return to the Stage
description: Sarah Ruhl, after a long struggle living with Bell’s palsy, knows the feeling of being masked among the unmasked.
content: In the theater, we smile. We smile because the show must go on. We smile, to quote Nat King Cole, even when our hearts are breaking. Unless we are performers in a tragedy, we put on some glitter and we sail out into the night, toward the theater district. Even writers, the least performative of the lot, smile. I didn’t want to be an opaque, judging playwright at auditions; I wanted to mirror the actors’ joy, or sadness, and partake of the strange communion between performers and their first audience. I never expected that one day, during a pandemic, we would all come to the theater masked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: They Didn’t Want to Sing Spirituals, but They Did — and Changed American Music
description: For 150 years, the Fisk Jubilee Singers have performed spirituals that saved a university and helped raise generations up from the bonds of slavery.
content: NASHVILLE — In an account of her years as assistant director of the Fisk Jubilee Singers, Ella Sheppard, a gifted musician who had been enslaved as a child, recalled one of the student ensemble’s earliest excursions outside Nashville, only a handful of years after the Civil War. The singers were all students at Fisk University, a school for emancipated former slaves. They were stranded at a rural train station with Ms. Sheppard and their director, a white abolitionist named George White, when an angry mob arrived. In the face of the white men’s fury, the students began to sing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: How Old Is the Maltese, Really?
description: Many dog fanciers like to trace their favorite breed to antiquity, but the researchers who study the modern and ancient DNA of dogs have a different perspective.
content: “The tiny Maltese,” the American Kennel Club tells us, “has been sitting in the lap of luxury since the Bible was a work in progress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Gone in Minutes, Out for Hours: Outage Shakes Facebook
description: When apps used by billions of people worldwide blinked out, lives were disrupted, businesses were cut off from customers — and some Facebook employees were locked out of their offices.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook and its family of apps, including Instagram and WhatsApp, were inaccessible for hours on Monday, taking out a vital communications platform used by billions and showcasing just how dependent the world has become on a company that is under intense scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Tom Brady Returns to Boos in New England but Leaves With a Win
description: Playing in New England for the first time since leaving for Tampa Bay, Brady set the N.F.L.’s career record for passing yards.
content: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Tom Brady’s much-hyped return to New England to face his former team, the Patriots, and his longtime coach, Bill Belichick, was not the homecoming he envisioned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Accuses Republicans of Being ‘Reckless’ Over Debt Limit Increase
description: The president warned Republicans “not to use procedural tricks to block us from doing the job.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden excoriated Republicans on Monday for blocking his party’s efforts to raise the debt ceiling weeks before a projected government default, calling their tactics “reckless” and “disgraceful” and warning they risked causing “a self-inflicted wound that takes our economy over a cliff.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Alaska’s doctors are forced to ration care.
content: Alaska is currently home to the nation’s worst Covid-19 outbreak, and doctors there are  facing the nightmare scenario of rationing care.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: London Police Announce Independent Review Amid Trust Crisis
description: The move comes as the force faces scrutiny and criticism over its handling of violence against women, after the sentencing last week of Sarah Everard’s killer.
content: LONDON — London’s Metropolitan Police on Monday announced an independent review into its culture and standards following damaging revelations about police behavior during the sentencing hearing last week for the police officer who killed a 33-year-old woman as she was walking home at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Egner
title: Damian Lewis Discusses the Future of ‘Billions’
description: In an interview, the actor talked about his character’s big twist and what it means for the Showtime series and his career.
content: This article includes spoilers from Sunday’s Season 5 finale of “Billions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Battling Delta, New Zealand Abandons Its Zero-Covid Ambitions
description: The country is changing course seven weeks into a lockdown that has failed to end the outbreak and tested the patience of many residents.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — For a year and a half, New Zealand has pursued a strategy of “Covid zero,” closing its borders and quickly enforcing lockdowns to keep the coronavirus in check, a policy it maintained even as other Asia-Pacific countries transitioned to coexisting with the viral threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Eight Killed as Tensions Around India’s Farm Protests Worsen
description: The police are investigating whether the son of one of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ministers was in a vehicle that slammed into protesters.
content: NEW DELHI — Eight people were killed on Sunday in an incident that protesting farmers said was the fault of the son of a prominent Indian leader, as nearly yearlong demonstrations against a government revamp of the country’s agriculture laws threatened to enter a more volatile phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford’s sales fell 27 percent in the third quarter because of chip shortages.
description: The automaker was forced to idle many of its plants for parts of August and September because it did not have enough electronic parts that use computer chips.
content: Ford Motor said Monday that its sales of new vehicles in the United States fell about 27 percent in the three months that ended in September from the same period a year earlier. The drop was in line with the rest of the auto industry, which has been hampered by a global shortage of computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand abandons its goal of eliminating the coronavirus.
description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand acknowledged an end on Monday to the country’s strategy of eliminating the coronavirus, announcing that restrictions would be gradually lifted in Auckland, the country’s largest city.
content: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand acknowledged an end on Monday to the country’s strategy of eliminating the coronavirus, announcing that restrictions would be gradually lifted in Auckland, the country’s largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Upcoming U.S.-China trade talks.
content: The Biden administration offered its strongest signal yet that the U.S. would maintain the combative economic approach toward China that was adopted under former President Trump, using trade barriers and other punitive measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil prices hit a seven-year high as OPEC and its allies stick with a modest increase.
description: OPEC Plus signed off on increasing production by 400,000 barrels a day next month, under a deal reached in July.
content: Oil prices hit their highest levels since 2014 as officials from OPEC, Russia and other oil producers decided on Monday to stick with their previous agreement to only gradually add oil to the market. The announcement came despite rising demand for energy as businesses around the world resumed operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: N.Y.C. Schools’ Vaccine Mandate Is in Place. 96% of Teachers Got a Shot.
description: The mandate is the first full vaccine requirement for any group of city workers and affects roughly 150,000 people. Thousands were compelled to get a shot in the past week, ahead of the deadline.
content: New York’s requirement that virtually everyone who works in the city’s public schools be vaccinated against the coronavirus compelled thousands of Department of Education employees to get at least one dose of a vaccine in the past week, leading to extremely high vaccination rates among educators, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Losing Your Hair? You Might Blame the Great Stem Cell Escape.
description: By observing mouse hair follicles, scientists discovered an unexpected mechanism of aging. “If I didn’t see it with my own eyes I wouldn't believe it,” one said.
content: Every person, every mouse, every dog, has one unmistakable sign of aging: hair loss. But why does that happen?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Pope Urges Clemency for Missouri Death Row Prisoner
description: Ernest L. Johnson, 61, is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday for killing three convenience store employees during a robbery in 1994. Supporters say his intellectual disabilities make the execution unconstitutional.
content: Pope Francis and two members of Congress have asked Missouri’s governor to stop the scheduled execution on Tuesday of a 61-year-old man, saying he should be spared because he is intellectually disabled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: A ‘Pacemaker for the Brain’: No Treatment Helped Her Depression — Until This
description: It’s the first study of individualized brain stimulation to treat severe depression. Sarah’s case raises the possibility the method may help people who don’t respond to other therapies.
content: Driving home from work in Northern California five years ago, a young woman was so overwhelmed with depression that all she could think about was ending her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: What’s Wrong With Kyrsten Sinema?
description: There’s a difference between being a maverick and being a narcissist.
content: In 2003, Joe Lieberman, at the time one of the worst Democratic senators, traveled to Arizona to campaign for his party’s presidential nomination and was regularly greeted by antiwar demonstrators. “He’s a shame to Democrats,” said the organizer of a protest outside a Tucson hotel, a left-wing social worker named Kyrsten Sinema. “I don’t even know why he’s running. He seems to want to get Republicans voting for him — what kind of strategy is that?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Drake Edged Out of No. 1 Spot by YoungBoy Never Broke Again
description: “Sincerely, Kentrell” narrowly beat Drake’s “Certified Lover Boy” to earn this Louisiana rapper his fourth Billboard chart-topping album in two years.
content: In a close race for No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, the new release by YoungBoy Never Broke Again, a 21-year-old from Baton Rouge, La., narrowly beat fourth-week sales for “Certified Lover Boy,” the streaming smash by Drake, who was dethroned after three straight weeks on top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Mets Part Ways With Manager After ‘Two Extremely Trying Years’
description: Following a devastating August collapse, and a second straight losing season, Luis Rojas will not return to the job for 2022.
content: After two losing seasons under Manager Luis Rojas, the Mets want a change. The team announced on Monday that it had declined the option for the 2022 season on Rojas’s contract, ending his tenure. The team was 103-119 under his watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Jean-Georges Vongerichten to Put His Stamp on the Tin Building
description: The chef’s company will run everything at the site — including markets, dining counters and restaurants — in his most ambitious project to date.
content: In his most ambitious project to date, the chef and restaurateur Jean-Georges Vongerichten will fill the Seaport District’s Tin Building with markets, dining counters and restaurants, to open in the spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
title: U.S. Signals No Thaw in Trade Relations With China
description: The Biden administration said it would not immediately remove the Trump administration’s tariffs and would require that Beijing uphold its trade commitments.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration offered its strongest signal yet that the United States’ combative economic approach toward China would continue, with senior administration officials saying that President Biden would not immediately lift tariffs on Chinese goods and that he would hold Beijing accountable for trade commitments agreed to during the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Six,’ All the Tudor Ladies Got Talent
description: The exuberant queenhood-is-powerful pageant about the wives of Henry VIII was shut down on opening night by the pandemic. Now it’s back, and it totally rules.
content: Are you an Elsa or an Anna? An Elphaba or a Glinda? Or, for those with more classic tastes, a Vera or a Mame?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Pithers
title: A Furniture Maker Working to Expand the Definition of British Design
description: The Nottingham- and Newcastle-based Mac Collins draws on a range of references, from midcentury Scandinavian pieces to his own Afro-Carribbean roots.
content: The first thing that strikes you about Mac Collins’s original ash-wood Iklwa chair is the color. A searing ultramarine, it references the celestial blue of Afrofuturism and, with its throne-like shape and spear-modeled armrests (an iklwa is a short stabbing spear innovated by the Zulu nation in the 19th century), is intended to invoke authority and entitlement. A more personal aspect is at play as well: The blue is the same shade as the tailored suit that Collins’s grandfather Clifton wore when he immigrated to England from Jamaica in 1955 as part of what is known in the UK as the Windrush Generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Swing Today: ‘Our Dance Is Modern Because We’re Alive Right Now’
description: Caleb Teicher’s “Sw!ng Out” at the Joyce Theater aims to bring swing onstage as it lives today in a program that’s part variety show, part hangout.
content: Choices picked out of a hat: It’s a gambit of magicians and improv comedians, a way of showing an audience that chance is at work and performers are creating on the fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: With Their Season on the Line, the Yankees Go to Their Go-to Guy
description: Gerrit Cole is known by his teammates as a student of the game. In a do-or-die game against Boston, the Yankees hope their $324 million ace has studied carefully.
content: On Sept. 19, as the Yankees were making a push for a wild-card spot in the postseason, they lost by 11-1 to Cleveland in a game in which their ace, Gerrit Cole, allowed seven runs. Walking into the clubhouse after the final out, reliever Michael King spotted Cole sitting in the locker of catcher Kyle Higashioka and doing something that fit his meticulous nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald Ayer
title: The Supreme Court Has Gone Off the Rails
description: Justices who once derided judicial “meddling” are now meddlers themselves.
content: The Supreme Court has final authority to make difficult judgment calls articulating the powers of government and the limits and constraints upon them. To merit the public trust, these judgments must not appear simply as assertions of individual value choices by the justices or willy-nilly discard long-established court precedents that profoundly affect people’s lives. Nor should they actively undermine the ability of governments to advance public purposes as established by a fair democratic process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong and Mihir Zaveri
title: Remembering Pvt. Danny Chen, at a Precarious Moment for Chinatown
description: Private Chen died by suicide at 19 after being hazed by fellow soldiers in Afghanistan. Ten years later, his family sought to uplift the community that raised him.
content: Before he was an Army private, before the events of his tragic death sparked a national reckoning over military hazing and rallied his neighbors to demand justice, before his name was on the street sign at the corner of Canal and Elizabeth Streets and his life had inspired an opera, Danny Chen was just a teenager from Chinatown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: One Justice Missing and Only One Masked, the Supreme Court Returns
description: As a term packed with major cases begins, much has changed since the last in-person arguments took place in March 2020.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court returned to its majestic mahogany bench on Monday after a pandemic-induced absence of more than 18 months, starting a new term that will include major cases on abortion and gun rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Elizabeth Warren Calls for an Insider Trading Inquiry at the Fed
description: The Democratic senator responded to news that the Fed’s vice chair shifted toward stocks shortly before a policy announcement last year.
content: Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, called on Monday for an investigation into whether top Federal Reserve officials engaged in insider trading in 2020, when some bought and sold securities that could have benefited from central bank policy moves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Should You Care about Unvaccinated N.B.A. Players?
description: On the virtues of ignoring famous people’s irrelevant opinions.
content: Last week, Kyrie Irving, the star guard for the Brooklyn Nets, missed the team’s media day at the Barclays Center. There was much speculation that Irving actually could not legally enter the building because of New York City’s proof-of-vaccination requirements, which, in turn, could preclude him from playing any games in cities with similar mandates. Irving, instead, chose to talk to reporters by video conference. When asked if he planned to play home games this season, Irving said, “Please respect my privacy regarding home games, what’s happening with my vaccination.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Homeless Shelter Executive Who Earns $1 Million a Year
description: Some executives who operate nonprofit homeless shelters have paid themselves generously, even as homelessness has surged to record levels in New York City.
content: It’s Monday. We’ll look at how executives at nonprofits that run homeless shelters earned large salaries, employed family members and sometimes doubled as for-profit vendors who provided services to their charities. And we’ll look at a school in Queens that counts Japan’s new prime minister as an alumnus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood Crew Union Votes to Authorize Strike Against Studios
description: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees is at loggerheads with companies like Netflix, Disney and Amazon over streaming pay and long workdays.
content: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood moved closer to a production shutdown on Monday after one of the film and television industry’s lower-profile unions said that members had overwhelmingly voted to authorize a strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Military Personnel in U.K. Begin Driving Fuel Trucks to Stem Shortage
description: A top government official said that supplies were improving but that wider disruptions could continue as the holiday season approaches.
content: Military personnel in Britain began driving fuel tankers on Monday as the government stepped up efforts to tackle a shortage of truck drivers that has closed some gas stations, caused panic buying and long lines at others, and threatened wider disruption in the run-up to Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Lovely Warren, Troubled Rochester Mayor, to Resign in Plea Deal
description: Ms. Warren will leave office early as part of a plea deal on campaign finance violations. The deal also resolves gun charges against her.
content: Lovely Warren, the embattled Democratic mayor of Rochester, N.Y., agreed to resign on Monday as part of a plea deal on several state criminal charges, capping a swift and staggering fall for a politician once considered a rising star in the state Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: In New Orleans, a Designer With a Daring, Completist Vision
description: A chronic experimenter, Bradley L. Bowers moves among the worlds of furniture, lighting and jewelry, challenging assumptions every step of the way.
content: The artist and designer Bradley L. Bowers does not have much regard for categorical distinctions. He creates wallpaper, jewelry, furniture, ceramics, lighting and textiles, as well as interiors and installation work. “I like to work with the material or medium that makes the most sense for the project at hand,” said Bowers, speaking from his New Orleans studio this past summer. “The thing that makes jewelry different from sculpture is it’s made out of silver, and it’s smaller. The only thing that really distinguishes them is the title. It’s all creative energy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Former Manchester United Player Condemns Racist Fan Song
description: Park Ji-Sung, who played soccer with the team from 2005 to 2012, said a song stereotyping Koreans was “very uncomfortable to me.”
content: Park Ji-Sung, a fan-favorite former player for Manchester United, asked the soccer club’s fans on Sunday to stop singing a song in his honor that includes the racist stereotype that Koreans eat dog meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Officer Faces Discipline 5 Years After Killing Mentally Ill Woman
description: Acquitted of murder in the death of Deborah Danner, Sgt. Hugh Barry is being brought up on administrative charges in a long-delayed hearing.
content: Police officers attempting to coax a schizophrenic woman out of her bedroom in the Bronx seemed on the verge of succeeding when Sgt. Hugh Barry made a grab for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: With 4 Color Books, Bryant Terry Looks to Color Outside the Lines
description: The chef and cookbook author is heading up a new imprint to give chefs of color a leg up in the historically insular publishing industry.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — “Can I show you my lab?” Bryant Terry asked before walking to a shed in his sunny, compact backyard. As wide as a king-size bed, the chef’s “lab” is a lofted work space with a standing desk and, on the floor, a striking framed photo of the musicians Ann Peebles and Al Green sitting barefoot on a porch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flo Wales Bonner
title: The Rug Designer Inspired by the Colors and Craft Traditions of India
description: Following one of many trips to her parents’ homeland, Arati Rao launched Tantuvi, which combines vibrant, abstract shapes with centuries-old weaving techniques.
content: India’s grandest Jantar Mantar, a grouping of oddly yet precisely shaped stone and marble structures that together form an astronomical observatory, is in Jaipur, and is especially known for its 74-foot-tall sundial. For Arati Rao, the founder of the Brooklyn-based rug and textiles company Tantuvi, the site is a wonder — partly because though it looks like a contemporary art installation, it was actually built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II in the early 18th century. “It always just blows my mind,” she says. “The curves, the lines — it feels so modern and fresh.” It’s a place that Rao, 39, goes on almost every trip she makes to India (pre-pandemic, she would typically visit once or twice a year) and that frequently sparks inspiration for her creations, which have abstract and geometric properties of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Christopher Mele
title: Gunfire on Amtrak Train: D.E.A. Agent Killed, 2nd Agent Is Critically Wounded
description: A suspect was dead and a Tucson officer wounded in the shooting, which erupted during a drug sweep of the train at a stop in Arizona, the police said.
content: A federal drug enforcement agent was killed and another was critically injured in a chaotic scene of gunfire aboard a crowded Amtrak train while it was stopped at a station in Tucson, Ariz., on Monday morning, the city’s police chief said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Like Captain Kirk, William Shatner Will Travel to Space (Almost)
description: It’s only the edge of space, but the man who played the “Star Trek” captain is heading there with three other people for Blue Origin’s second flight with passengers.
content: He’s boldly going where Jeff Bezos has gone before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Meatto
title: Teaching About the Native American Fight for Representation, Repatriation and Recognition
description: In this teaching resource, we provide six short lesson plans about the actions that Native Americans are taking to redress past wrongs and foster a better future.
content: We have selected six Times articles published in the last year that feature stories of Native Americans who are fighting to ensure representation, repatriation and recognition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 4, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 4, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan, Clifford Krauss and Ivan Penn
title: California Oil Spill Closes Beaches and Renews Call for Drilling Ban
description: A pipeline transporting oil from offshore platforms spilled at least 126,000 gallons of oil in Southern California, the state’s largest such leak since 2015.
content: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. — The most prominent visible sign on Monday of the major offshore oil spill that threatened some of Southern California’s most popular beaches was a single strip of yellow caution tape blocking the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Bluestone
title: Matthew Rhys Hits the Seas
description: The actor bought a wooden boat on a whim. It has taken him on a journey.
content: Matthew Rhys never planned on buying an old wooden boat that would take four years, tens of thousands of dollars and quite a bit of his own manual labor to restore. But one night he was drinking whiskey and clicking through eBay, and, well, one thing led to another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Whimsical Pumpkins With a Twist
description: The art-glass pumpkins from Simon Pearce in Vermont are eye-catching additions to the dinner table.
content: For fall, Simon Pearce, the Vermont company known for tableware and decorative accessories, has become pumpkin central. The company has introduced a new line of beautiful art-glass pumpkins, crystal clear with intricate twisted stems, for your elegant harvest or Thanksgiving table. They’re a more elaborate version of the plain large glass pumpkin the company has made in the past (which is still available, $230). The new Pumpkins With a Twist come in three sizes: small (about four inches, $125), medium (about six inches, $175) and large (about nine inches, $240). There are also glazed pottery pumpkins in sunset, a honey tone, and candent gray, medium ($165) and large ($230), all with no practical purpose beyond admiration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Rome Mayor Loses Re-election Bid, a Defeat for Five Star Movement
description: In five years in office, Virginia Raggi failed to stem the dysfunction of Italy’s capital, where voters will choose between two of her rivals in a runoff.
content: ROME — Voters on Monday resoundingly rejected the re-election bid of Rome’s mayor, Virginia Raggi of the Five Star Movement, who swept into power five years ago promising change but was unable to turn around the degradation of services and quality of life that has become a hallmark of the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: In New York, a Magazine Editor Who’s Also a Furniture Maker
description: This year, Emmanuel Olunkwa was named the editor of Pin-Up — and debuted his own playful yet minimalist designs.
content: When the designer and writer Emmanuel Olunkwa lived with roommates, he would lie on the couch and consider the apartment, all the things in it and how they could be different. “I would think, ‘What if that could go there? Is that big enough? Does that make sense? Do I want — ’” At this point in reciting his list of self-prompts, the 27-year-old broke out into a crash of laughter. “I’ve always gotten into trouble for being overly analytic,” he’d tell me, later in our conversation. Nonetheless, it’s a quality that drives him. Olunkwa, whose practice includes furniture design, architecture, editing, writing and producing the occasional radio show, is ceaselessly probing and interrogating the world around him — and the world he wants to create.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aileen Kwun
title: The Textile Artist Employing Centuries-Old Practices and Pop Culture Imagery
description: For Sarah Zapata, hand-weaving is a metaphor for both expressing and examining different facets of her identity.
content: As a queer undergrad studying fiber arts and weaving at the University of North Texas, the artist Sarah Zapata was wary of color. “Using it made me really nervous, which is so hilarious now,” she says, smiling through neon orange tresses. “There’s so much power that exists within color. There’s so much joy and beauty, as well as darkness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden Officials End Ban on Abortion Referrals at Federally Funded Clinics
description: The change reversed a policy meant to deter abortions under the Trump administration.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday reversed a contentious policy set under President Donald J. Trump that barred organizations that provide abortion referrals from receiving federal family planning money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: The Stock Market’s Hot Summer Became a Swoon. Where Does It Go Next?
description: Inflation and supply chain problems have been a concern since the pandemic began. But action by the Federal Reserve and pressure on corporate profits put those worries in sharp focus.
content: Just four weeks ago, the stock market looked unstoppable. Seven straight months of gains had left the S&P 500 index up 21 percent for the year, corporations enjoyed record profits and economists predicted the fastest growth in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Making Very Short Memories at Givenchy and Lanvin
description: At Paris Fashion Week, the recent past is the reference.
content: PARIS — In one of the more unexpected runway trends of the moment, the middle-aged model is hot. (Also the edging toward middle-age-in-model-terms model.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: What’s a Little Disagreement Among Factions?
description: Everything is going just the way Biden dreamed it up.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I have a new grand theory of politics: The Stupid Party is whichever party happens to be in power. Fair?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: A Pillar of the European Order Has Collapsed
description: The Christian Democratic Union was Germany’s great stabilizing bourgeois party.
content: The drubbing inflicted on Germany’s Christian Democratic Union in the country’s recent elections is a sign that, alongside Chancellor Angela Merkel’s 16-year stint in power, something larger is coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: How the ‘Many Saints of Newark’ Stars Remade Key ‘Sopranos’ Roles
description: Actors in the prequel had to put their stamp on favorite characters from the original series, whether they had watched it or not.
content: From its debut in 1999 to its blackout finale in 2007, “The Sopranos” set a seemingly unsurpassable benchmark for acting. The cast members of that HBO crime drama, leading players and supporting performers alike, became synonymous with the menacing mobsters and manipulative family members they portrayed. When it was all over, you couldn’t imagine anyone else playing those roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: The European Medicines Agency said that a booster shot of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine can be given to healthy adults.
description: The E.U.’s main drug regulator also said that extra doses of the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines can be given to those with underlying health conditions as early as 28 days after the second dose.
content: The European Medicines Agency, the European Union’s main drug regulator, said on Monday that a booster shot of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine can be given to healthy adults at least six months after the second dose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Acknowledging the Missing and Those Who Try to Find Them
description: To document the crisis of Mexico’s disappeared, the photographer Fred Ramos followed families in their search and documented the clothing that dressed unidentified bodies.
content: Nearly 100,000 people have disappeared in Mexico since 1964, many of them victims of the country’s seemingly endless drug war. The grim phenomenon has left thousands of families searching, sometimes futilely, through deserts and other rural areas in hopes of locating the missing. And it has also resulted in countless unidentified bodies at morgues throughout the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Carlisle Floyd: Artists Share Memories of a Composer
description: The writer of “Susannah” and other operas is remembered by a tenor, a conductor and an impresario who worked closely with him.
content: The career of the American composer Carlisle Floyd, who died on Thursday at 95, spanned nearly 70 years and the heydays of a host of musical styles. But through them all, Floyd stayed stubbornly true to himself and his vision: creating operas with clear, strong narratives — often about intolerance and social outcasts — and scores grounded in tonality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Thailand’s Quarantine-Island Experiment Is Showing (Modest) Results
description: Phuket, a resort island where vaccinated people who test negative for the coronavirus can roam freely, is starting to see some life return to its tourism industry.
content: PHUKET, Thailand — Three months ago, with great fanfare, Thailand began a campaign to start reviving its crucial tourism industry by letting visitors who follow strict Covid-19 protocols roam freely on the resort island of Phuket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Daniel Victor
title: Todd Akin, Whose Senate Bid Collapsed After a Rape Remark, Dies at 74
description: The former Republican representative from Missouri was widely criticized after saying in 2012 that women’s bodies could reject pregnancies that were the result of a sexual assault.
content: Todd Akin, a six-term Republican representative from Missouri who gave up a safe House seat to run for the Senate in 2012, only to see his campaign collapse in a hail of recriminations after a remark about “legitimate rape,” died on Sunday at his home in Wildwood, Mo., a St. Louis suburb. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Guggenheim Gets New Chairman, and Second Ever Black Female Trustee
description: ‭The museum’s board will be led by the financier J. Tomilson Hill and joined by the poet Claudia Rankine.
content: At a time when the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is working to address charges from within its own ranks that it is “an inequitable work environment that enables racism,” the museum on Monday appointed a new chairman, the billionaire collector J. Tomilson Hill, and elected its second ever Black female trustee, the poet, playwright and essayist Claudia Rankine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: ‘The Beginning of the Snowball’: Supply-Chain Snarls Delay Books
description: Shipping delays, printer backups and worker shortages are forcing publishers to postpone new titles and leaving booksellers in a lurch for some old ones.
content: Days after the release of Rebecca Donner’s book, “All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days,” its hardcover edition sold out on Amazon, then at the online retailer Bookshop.org and at Powell’s Books. When it made its debut on the New York Times best-seller list, the country’s largest book retailer didn’t have any copies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Global trade is accelerating, but poorer countries need vaccines to keep up, the W.T.O. says.
description: The World Trade Organization now forecasts global merchandise trade to grow 10.8 percent in 2021, up from the 8 percent it forecast in March, as the flow of goods recovers from last year’s slump.
content: Global trade recovered from its pandemic lows faster than anticipated in the first half of 2021 and is set to grow more quickly than expected next year, lifting global growth forecasts, the World Trade Organization said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: New York’s largest health care provider fires 1,400 unvaccinated employees.
description: Northwell Health, which employs 76,000 people, says ensuring that all staff are vaccinated will help improve care.
content: Northwell Health, New York State’s largest health care provider, announced on Monday that 1,400 employees — less than 2 percent of its staff —  refused to get vaccinated against the coronavirus and had to leave their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Covid, in Retreat
description: New cases in the U.S. have fallen by more than a third in the past month.
content: Covid-19 is once again in retreat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Man Who Put French Soccer at Risk Says It’s Not His Fault
description: When Jaume Roures and Mediapro walked away from a billion-dollar TV contract, Ligue 1 teams felt the squeeze. But he says they have a bigger problem.
content: Sitting alone on a long table inside a committee room deep inside France’s national assembly, the Spanish businessman tried to explain why things had gone wrong, so very wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: How Do You Win a Do-or-Die Game in Fenway? These Guys Know.
description: In 1978, Bucky Dent and Ron Guidry stepped up to lead the Yankees past the Red Sox and into the playoffs. Lessons they learned that day can translate for the current club.
content: When asked how the Yankees could get past the Boston Red Sox in a wild-card game that could extend or end a season that has had countless ups and downs, Bucky Dent had some tongue-in-cheek advice: “Use Mickey Rivers’s bat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Bubba Wallace Gets a Breakthrough NASCAR Victory at Talladega
description: Wallace’s NASCAR Cup win was the first by a Black driver since 1963 and also the inaugural victory in the sport’s top series for Michael Jordan, the co-owner of Wallace’s team.
content: A little more than a year after almost single-handedly forcing American auto racing to confront the sport’s longstanding issues with racism, Darrell Wallace Jr., known as Bubba, became just the second Black winner in NASCAR’s top series, finishing first at a rain-shortened event at Talladega Superspeedway on Monday afternoon.

author: By Nick Sywak
title: An In-Demand Maker of Poetic, Off-Kilter Furniture
description: Minjae Kim’s sculptural pieces, from rabbit-eared wood and fiberglass chairs to a desk inspired by Henri Matisse’s cutouts, have earned him a devoted following.
content: Minjae Kim’s studio in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is littered with blocks of wood being shaped into something more, but only two pieces in the space appear to be finished: a lamp in one corner resembling a giant oyster and pearl on a pedestal, a self-illuminating sculpture poised somewhere between art and design; and, on the wall above, a painting by his mother, MyoungAe Lee. If his work space leaves an inchoate impression on this August afternoon, it’s likely because the 32-year-old designer hasn’t had time to fully inhabit it, having quit his job at the prestigious design firm Studio Giancarlo Valle only a few weeks earlier in order to become a furniture designer full-time. His decision to venture out on his own was the culmination of a heady year and a half, during which Kim established himself as one of the most sought-after furniture makers in the contemporary design space, using primarily wood and fiberglass to fashion chairs, tables, lamps and cabinets possessed of a poetic, off-kilter presence. “It’s very wild,” he says of his recent dizzying ascent. “It gives me some anxiety, too, because I feel like it could go away so easily.”

title: How a Design Devotee Turned Her Passion Into a Thriving Business

content: Maggie Holladay was a collector of design objects with a serious tchotchke-hoarding habit — accumulating marble ashtrays and espresso demitasses by the dozen, to cite just two examples — when her then boyfriend staged an intervention. His advice was to stop amassing and start selling. Holladay agreed, and before long she’d graduated from knickknacks to more substantial pieces. “I started out with little marketplace finds, but then found one amazing item and made a huge profit off it,” she says; it was a modular channel bouclé sofa she sold to the model Elsa Hosk, who bought it prior to an Architectural Digest shoot featuring her SoHo apartment. That such a transaction was eminently iterative was not lost on her: “I repeated this process of saving up to buy one really great item and reselling it,” she says.

content: Last month, the Biden administration announced that it had cleared a makeshift tent camp where thousands of Haitians had congregated under a bridge linking Mexico and Del Rio, Texas. The administration’s unsteady response to this crisis has revealed, once again, the broken nature of this country’s asylum system.
